awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer for Chemical Mapping of Evolving Surfaces:  A Regional Instrument for Research and Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program and the Division of Materials Research (DMR), the University of Virginia (UVa) will acquire an X-Ray Photoelectron Spectrometer (XPS) with integrated sample preparation chambers.  The instrument will be used to probe and understand changes in material surfaces during chemical reactions.  XPS quantitatively determines the elemental/chemical composition, empirical formula, and electronic state of elements within materials.  The data from this analytical technique will be used to explore evolving chemistry during surface reactions relevant for catalysis, weathering, and advanced material systems.  This knowledge will impact our understanding of catalysis, astrochemistry, geochemistry, and materials stability for use in extremely corrosive or high temperature reactive environments.  These scientific endeavors will impact such diverse topics as synthesis of fuels and chemicals, our understanding of the solar system, management of fracking, and development of improved materials for corrosion and oxidation resistance.  The award will also enhance the education and training of students.  A multi-level education plan will introduce the fundamentals of XPS and its applications in courses at both the undergraduate and graduate levels at the University of Virginia.  A web-based lecture series on XPS will be developed which can be integrated into courses at other colleges and universities.  Outreach activities will involve middle school, high school, and community college students in hands-on XPS activities.  The instrument will also be used throughout the Charlottesville region for research and teaching collaborations with surrounding industries, colleges and universities through the UVa "XPS-Hub".

The instrument will enhance research across disciplines, especially in areas such as (a) understanding atomic scale mechanisms during oxide formation; (b) tailoring catalyst surfaces to promote cascade reactions for synthesis of chemicals; (c) understanding hydrocarbon bond-breaking for design of high throughput alloy catalysts; (d) investigating aqueous alterations in minerals representative of asteroids, meteorites, and lunar soils; (e) studying the chemical formation of organic molecular species on mineral substrates of importance for understanding the origin of life in the solar system; (f) clarification of carbonation reactions to diminish risks associated with hydraulic fracturing; (g) investigating preferential oxidation or volatilization of multi-component material systems for improved stability at high temperatures; (h) controlling surface microstructural and chemical heterogeneity to improve aqueous corrosion resistance; and (i) developing laser-driven surface modification methods for advanced manufacturing of high-performance metal alloys.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to acquire an X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer (XPS) system with an adjacent sample preparation and processing chamber for scientists and researchers at UVa and in the surrounding Central Virginia region. In addition, we planned educational and outreach activities highlighting the XPS instrument and surface analytical techniques involving students at UVa, XPS-hub partner-institutions, Piedmont Valley Community College/Charlottesville High School, and the public-at-large.
 An XPS instrument is a specialized tool for identifying and quantifying the top-most ten nanometers of a material -- this thickness is about one millionth the eye of a needle. Understanding the surface composition and chemistry of a material can be very important, as this is the portion of the solid that comes in contact with the environment around it. Thus, a metal alloy surface may have a significantly different composition from its bulk stoichiometry when after coming in contact with the wet, salty environment of the oceans, or with the corrosive environment of an industrial city where nitrous or sulfuric oxides react with water to produce acid rain. Surface chemistry is important in many fields, including biomedical engineering of medical devices such as hip or knee implants, high-temperature ceramics found in airplane engines, fuel cells (batteries) to store energy, corrosion of metals in bridges, buildings, and ships, dental implants, contacts and devices for nanomaterials and technology, the effect of water with different PH-levels on soils in rivers and lakes or on coral or volcanic deposits, identification of meteorite-impact-related vapor-deposited materials on the surface of lunar grains, compositional analysis of thin films and thin-film interfaces, and many more!
We purchased and installed a Physical Electronics Versaprobe III Scanning-XPS Microprobe with adjacent ultra-high vacuum preparation chamber and high-pressure reaction cell in December 2017. The instrument is located in the Materials Science Building, Room 148, and maintained by the Nanoscale Materials Characterization Facility (NMCF) at UVa. Over the duration of this NSF award, the Versaprobe XPS has resulted in at least twenty-two peer-reviewed scientific publications, with several others in progress and at least eleven conference proceedings. In addition, over its operating life at UVa (~1.8 years) the XPS instrument usage continues to grow, increasing from an average of 224 hours/month for the final 6-months of FY 2017-2018 to 378 hours/month for FY 2018-2019 to 434 hours/month for the first 8 months of FY 2019-2020. We are nearing the practical limit for 24 hour/7 day-a-week operation after calibration, maintenance, and contingency time. 
A total of sixty-four researchers and students have been trained to use the Versaprobe III independently, with a small subset (~10) scientists additionally utilizing the adjacent preparation and reaction chamber. The majority of trained XPS users are graduate students (Ph.D. & M.S.), with approximately ten post-doctoral researchers making up a significant minority; five undergraduates have also been certified.
Research at UVa utilizing the XPS includes: the study of anodic TiO2 nanotubes which may be a potential candidate for industrial scale and stable photoelectrochemical water oxidation. [Xu et al. 2019]; identification and quantification of volatile species (Ir, S, K, Na, etc.) in Apollo 17 lunar material [Dukes et a. 2019]; understanding the effects of space weathering on hydrated, organic-rich materials, maximizing scientific return from remote sensing data and preparing for the analysis of returned samples from NASA and JAXA space missions [Laczniak et al., 2019]; designing a novel method of laser annealing to produce perovskite crystallization for solar cell without degradation of sub-layers due to heating [Wilkes et al. 2018], looking at how sea-water PH effects the formation of blue-crab shells [Fantasia et al. 2019], as well as many other studies.
Our outreach projects consisted of developing a continuing XPS lecture series, available online for new users located at UVa and at universities participating in the XPS-Hub. Regular annual tours of the XPS facility have been integrated into four UVa undergraduate/graduate courses: Characterization of Materials; Surface Science; Geochemistry, and Isotope Geochemistry. REU summer students from JMU visited UVa in 2019 and participated in a tour and discussion of XPS analysis, instrumentation, and practical application. A website for the XPS parent facility, the Nanoscale Materials Characterization Facility, was created with an instrument page for the Versaprobe III: https://engineering.virginia.edu/nmcf-xps. XPS instrument demonstrations and discussions were integrated into two well-established UVa institutional activities: the annual Engineering School Open House and Nanodays, an event with activities such as hands-on experimentations, and exhibits related to research and exploration of nanoscale phenomena. Engineering students at Piedmont Virginia Community College (PVCC) were invited to visit the XPS instrument and tour the entire NMCF facility; Associate of Engineering students have been invited to apply for bi-weekly Fall 2019 internships to produce XPS instrument standard practice and procedure videos. We provided examples of XPS elemental and chemical analysis for 3D printing materials, used in several courses and engineering clubs utilizing the CHS Sigma Lab.
